By James Clay

By James Clay

Student volunteers acknowledged during Student Volunteering Week 2023

By James Clay

Plans for future investment in housing and infrastructure are being debated by the local council

By Gracie Daw

Action on 21, 22, 23, 27, 28 February and 1 and 2 March will not go ahead

By James Clay

Pierrick Roger re-elected as YUSU President

Video made the political star

Jennifer O'Mahony looks at the students who have harnessed the potential of YouTube as a means of campaigning

Plans for Union bar in Langwith unveiled

Plans for the redevelopment of Langwith bar have made further progress, with a finalised choice of building contractor and the release of designs for the new venue.

Council motion threatens students through restrictions on off-campus accommodation

YUSU President Anne-Marie Canning has strongly criticised plans by York County Council to restrict levels of students living in certain areas, labelling the decision "obscene".

Student to feature in year-long TV show

Claire Hazelgrove, a second year politics student running for Parliament, is to have a year of her life documented for a program for Channel 4.

York learns from defeat of NUS review

YUSU is planning a wide program of consultation in the run to the governance review in the hope of avoiding a membership defeat like that suffered at the recent NUS annual conference.

Generous GSA budget questioned

The Graduate Student Association's (GSA) large budget of PS140,000 has come under increased scrutiny the debate on funding levels continues.

BBC explores lesbianism at York

A recently aired BBC documentary saw a York academic discussing the fluidity of female sexuality.

Charity slams Hes. East greenbelt plans

Plans for the Heslington East campus development have been heavily criticised by the environmental group Campaign to Protect Rural England.

FTR prices unlikely to fall despite trial week success

FTR has declared that the trial week of a PS2 return bus fare into the city centre has "certainly been a success" but did not suggest that prices were likely to be lowered.

Looking forward to a year of campaigns

The University of York is set to witness a number of student campaigns getting underway over the course of the next year.

Closet couple disturb lecture in Langwith

A first-year History lecture was interrupted in Week Two after students became distracted by continual banging noises in an adjacent room.

Lake swim leaves student hospitalised

A York student was rushed to hospital last Tuesday after having spent 45 minutes in the University lake.

Amnesty 'sleep-out' planned on campus

Members of the York Amnesty Society are planning a 12 hour sleep out as part of a campaign to highlight the plight of failed asylum seekers in the UK.

Report strongly criticises YUSU's poor structure

By James Bithell

YUSU's current structure shows levels of sabbatical work overload "so extreme that is was unhealthy for the post holder," according to a recent report.

BNP leaflets delivered through internal mail

Police are investigating allegations that a BNP campaigner posed as a member of University staff in order to distribute leaflets through campus' internal mail system.

Metamorphosis scoops six awards at Drama Festival

By James Bithell

Students from the Drama Society took six awards for their production of Metamorphosis at the National Student Drama Festival.

Bridge set to be demolished this weekend

The anticipated removal of the Langwith-Alcuin bridge is to take place this Easter weekend, it has been revealed, in line with the plans to remove unsafe bridges across campus.

Pirate wins presidency

Pirate candidate Mad Cap'n Tom Scott has won the YUSU Presidency after securing 40.3% of an unprecedented 2,986 votes. His unexpected victory has provoked an immediate backlash on campus.

Counselling Service admits breach of trust after releasing over 300 emails

The University Counselling Service has admitted a "serious breach of trust" after releasing the email addresses of over three hundred students and staff taking counselling.

Vice-Chancellor denies Heslington East expansion costs damaging to University

University of York Vice-Chancellor Brian Cantor has denied that the Heslington East expansion project has had any negative effects on the University.

Anger at slow Economics Marking

The Economics Department has been forced to heed to pressure from students who voiced their outrage after being told to wait an unprecedented nineteen weeks for exam results.

University condemns Vision article

The University Equal Opportunities Office and YUSU Racial Equality Officers have criticised campus tabloid York Vision for a "highly sensationalist" and "misinformed" article on minority students at the University.

Student hospitalised after drink is spiked at Ziggy's

A University of York student has become the victim of a drink spiking incident following a recent drum and bass event at Ziggy's nightclub.

Motion to remove diversity officers fails

The future of liberation officers within the Student Union has been secured after a UGM motion to abolish the positions failed to pass.

Fines for inappropriate rituals

Policy is to be put in place to fine societies and sports teams that include vulgar rituals as part of their initiation ceremonies, according to the University's Pro-Vice-Chancellor for Students Jane Grenville.

Student quits university after break-in trauma

An Alcuin student has left the University after a theft in her accommodation block left her anxious and traumatised.

Benefactor Jack Lyons dies at 92

Jack Lyons, the controversial businessman and arts enthusiast who provided the funding for the Music Department and concert hall at the University of York has died at the age of 92.

NUS delegates to represent campus view

York student qualifies as local magistrate

York student Adam Quigley has become one of the youngest magistrates in the UK.

York to hold first graduation in China
